Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Target Specificity of Cysteine Desulfurases in Bacillus Subtilis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Sulfur-containing cofactors participate in a wide range of essential biological reactions. Although sulfur has long been recognized as indispensable to protein cofactors, its incorporation into biomolecules is not completely understood. In most organisms, the recruitment of sulfur for the synthesis of several cofactors involves the participation of a single general enzyme, cysteine desulfurase. The recruitment of such a promiscuous enzyme therefore poses an experimental challenge for dissecting the specific mechanisms of sulfur mobilization because its inactivation affects the synthesis of most sulfur cofactors. Gram-positive microbes such as Bacillus subtilis, on the other hand, code for several distinct cysteine desulfurases. Based on their genomic location, coding sequences, and preliminary analyses, the lab hypothesizes that each has specialized functions in sulfur metabolism. Using a combination of molecular genetics, biochemical and spectroscopic approaches, the lab will investigate the specific catalytic mechanisms by which these enzymes mobilize sulfur and their participation in the biosynthesis of sulfur cofactors using Bacillus subtilis as the model organism. This project will (i) establish the evolutionary importance of the differentiation and specialization of cysteine desulfurases; (ii) define key aspects of their structural, mechanistic, and functional relationships; and (iii) provide an excellent model system to study sulfur-trafficking reactions uncoupled from iron-sulfur metabolism. Successful results will transform our understanding of life-sustaining reactions and the intersections of metabolic pathways in the synthesis of essential sulfur cofactors.

Broader Impact
The broader impacts of this CAREER project will include the involvement of graduate students from Wake Forest University and undergraduate students from neighboring institutions in a mentored research/professional development program. The support team comprised of graduate students and instructors will develop a career plan for the students, which will include summer research experience and participation in professional development activities and meetings during the academic year. This program aims to broaden the scientific research preparation and participation of underrepresented groups in science. The team-mentoring approach will also have an impact on participating graduate students and their training as future teacher-scholars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sulfur is an essential chemical element required for all forms of life on Earth. Besides its presence in proteins, sulfur is also a critical constituent of several cofactors enabling a wide range of biochemical processes. All known living organisms use thiomolecules, including biotin, thiamine, lipoic acid, Fe-S clusters, molybdenum cofactor, and thionucleosides in tRNA, rRNA, and DNA, in various aspects of metabolism. Thus, defining reactions involving thiocofactor synthesis is crucial to understand distinct evolutionary strategies used to activate and traffic sulfur in biological systems.

The sulfur source for the biosynthesis of thiocofactors in bacteria and eukaryotic species is the free amino acid cysteine. Enzymes known as cysteine desulfurases catalyze sulfur transfer from cysteine to acceptor molecules. The Bacillus subtilis genome encodes four cysteine desulfurases (SufS, NifS, NifZ, and YrvO). This award enabled the mechanistic and functional investigation of these enzymes and their role in the biosynthesis of thio-cofactors in B. subtilis. This research established that the activities of cysteine desulfurases are modulated by the presence of their specific sulfur acceptor protein partners. The sulfur acceptor of SufS is SufU, which contains a tightly bound zinc at the active site. The involvement of zinc in sulfur transfer reactions expanded the inventory of biological chemistries involving this transition metal.  Two additional cysteine desulfurase and sulfur acceptor pairs have also been characterized; NifZ-ThiI and YrvO-MmnA are involved in the formation of 4-thiouridine and 2-thiouridine tRNA respectively. The recurring conclusion from studying these enzymes was that the specificity of cysteine desulfurases is a result of bidirectional protein-protein interactions between cysteine desulfurases and sulfur acceptor proteins. As a result, the target specificity of B. subtilis cysteine desulfurases is controlled by the recruitment of selected sulfur acceptor proteins participating in specific pathways.

The activities of this CAREER project enabled training of 7 PhD students and 40 Wake Forest undergraduate students. This award also enabled students from neighboring institutions to participate in research and professional development activities at Wake Forest. A total of 21 students from Salem College (all women’s college), Winston-Salem State University (HBCU), Bennett College (all women’s HBCU college), and Guilford College were mentored by 14 different Wake Forest faculty from departments of Chemistry, Biology, and Physics. Among the 21 fellows, 18 were female and 6 were either African American or Latino.  This program not only provided a hands-on research experiences for these students, but also enabled development of mentoring practices and identification of new role models by involving graduate students as co-mentors. To the large majority of students, this experience was their first exposure to research during their undergraduate education.
